column1: For urine specific gravity, the health care provider uses a dipstick made with a color-sensitive pad.
Your provider will ask you to temporarily stop any medicines that may affect the test results.

Increased urine concentration may be due to different conditions, such as: - Heart failure - Loss of body fluids (dehydration) from diarrhea or excessive sweating - Narrowing of the kidney artery (renal arterial stenosis) - Sugar, or glucose, in the urine - Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) - Vomiting Decreased urine concentration may indicate: - Diabetes insipidus - Drinking too much fluid - Kidney failure (loss of ability to reabsorb water) - Severe kidney infection (pyelonephritis)
